pli-tv-kd5:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha on the Vulture Peak.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.2: At that time King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha ruled over eighty thousand villages.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.3: And at Campā there was a prominent merchant who had a son called Soṇa Koḷivisa. He had been raised in great comfort
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.4: and even had hairs growing on the soles of his feet.
pli-tv-kd5:1.1.5: On one occasion, because of some business, King Bimbisāra had the chiefs of those eighty thousand villages gathered. He then sent a message to Soṇa,
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.2: “Soṇa, the king wishes to see your feet,
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.3: but don’t point your feet at the King.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.4: If you just sit down cross-legged in front of the King,
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.5: he’ll be able to see them.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.6: And they sent him away on a palanquin.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.7: Soṇa then approached King Bimbisāra, bowed, and sat down cross-legged in front of him.
pli-tv-kd5:1.2.8: And the King saw the hairs growing on the soles of his feet.
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.1: Then, after instructing those eighty thousand chiefs in worldly matters, the King dismissed them, saying,
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.3: Now go and visit the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.4: He will instruct us about the afterlife.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.3.5: Those eighty thousand chiefs then went to the Vulture Peak.
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.1: There they approached Venerable Sāgata, who at that time was the Buddha’s attendant.
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.3: “Venerable, these eighty thousand chiefs have come to visit the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd5:1.4.5: “Well then, please wait here for a moment, while I announce you to the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.1: Then, while those eighty thousand chiefs were watching, he sunk into the stone slab he was standing on and emerged in front of the Buddha. And he said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.2: “Venerable Sir, eighty thousand chiefs have come to visit you.
pli-tv-kd5:1.5.4: “Well then, Sāgata, please prepare a seat in the shade of the dwelling.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.6.2: He took a stool, sunk down in front of the Buddha, and as those eighty thousand chiefs were watching, he once more emerged from that stone slab. He then prepared a seat in the shade of the dwelling,
pli-tv-kd5:1.6.3: and the Buddha came out and sat down.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.1: Those eighty thousand chiefs approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.2: But they were preoccupied with Sāgata, not with the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.3: After reading the minds of those eighty thousand chiefs, the Buddha said to Sāgata,
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.4: “Well then, Sāgata, show us more superhuman abilities, more wonders of supernormal power.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.7.5: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” he rose up into the air, walked back and forth in space, and he stood, sat down, and lay down there. He emitted smoke and fire, and then disappeared.
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.1: After this display of supernormal powers, he bowed down at the feet of the Buddha, and said,
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.6: Those eighty thousand chiefs thought, “It’s astonishing and amazing
pli-tv-kd5:1.8.7: that even a disciple should be so powerful and mighty. Imagine what the teacher must be like!” And now they paid attention to the Buddha, not to Sāgata.
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.1: Having read their minds, the Buddha gave those eighty thousand chiefs a progressive teaching:
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.2: talk on generosity, talk on morality, talk on heaven; and he revealed the danger, degradation, and defilement in worldly pleasures, and the benefit of renunciation.
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.3: When the Buddha knew that their minds were ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas:
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.4: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path.
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.5: And just as a clean and stainless cloth takes the dye properly,
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.6: so too, while they were sitting right there, those eighty thousand chiefs experienced the stainless vision of the Truth:
pli-tv-kd5:1.9.7: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.1: They had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it; they had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction. They then said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.3: Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.4: those with eyes might see what’s there—
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.5: just so has the Buddha made the Teaching clear in many ways.
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.6: We go for refuge to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.7: to the Teaching, and to the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd5:1.10.8: Please accept us as lay followers who have gone for refuge for life.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.0: The going forth of Soṇa Koḷivisa
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.2: “The way I understand the Buddha’s Teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.3: Why don’t I cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.11.4: When those eighty-four thousand chiefs had rejoiced and expressed their appreciation for the Buddha’s teaching, they got up from their seats, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with their right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.1: Soon after they had left, Soṇa approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.3: “Sir, the way I understand the Buddha’s Teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.4: I want to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.5: Please give me the going forth.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.6: And Soṇa received the going forth and the full ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
pli-tv-kd5:1.12.7: Soon after his ordination, while staying in Cool Grove,
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.1: Venerable Soṇa walked up and down with so much energy that his feet cracked.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.2: His walking-path was soaked in blood, as if a slaughterhouse.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.3: Then, while he was in seclusion, he thought,
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.4: “I’m one of the Buddha’s energetic disciples,
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.5: yet my mind isn’t freed from the corruptions without grasping.
pli-tv-kd5:1.13.8: Perhaps I should return to the lower life, enjoy wealth, and make merit?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.1: Just then the Buddha read Soṇa’s mind.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.2: And, as a strong man might bend or stretch out his arm, so the Buddha disappeared from the Vulture Peak and appeared in Cool Grove.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.3: Soon afterwards as the Buddha and a number of monks were walking about the dwellings, they came to Soṇa’s walking-path.
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.4: The Buddha looked at it and asked the monks,
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.5: “Whose walking-path is this? It’s soaked in blood, as if a slaughterhouse.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.14.6: And they told him what had happened.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.1: The Buddha then approached Soṇa’s dwelling and sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.3: and the Buddha said to him,
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.4: “Soṇa, when you were in seclusion, didn’t you think,
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.5: ʻI’m one of the Buddha’s energetic disciples,
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.6: yet my mind isn’t freed from the corruptions without grasping.
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.9: Perhaps I should return to the lower life, enjoy wealth, and make merit’?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.11: “Think about it, Soṇa. When you were previously a householder, weren’t you a skilled lute player?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.15.13: “When the strings were too tight, was the lute melodious and easy to play?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.1: “When the strings were too loose, was the lute melodious and easy to play?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.3: “But when the strings were neither too tight nor too loose, but set to a balanced tension, was the lute then melodious and easy to play?”
pli-tv-kd5:1.16.5: “Just so, Soṇa, too much energy leads to restlessness and too little to laziness.
pli-tv-kd5:1.17.1: So exert a balanced energy and discover an evenness of the spiritual faculties. And that is where you should take up the meditation object.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.17.3: Then, as a strong man might bend or stretch out his arm, so too the Buddha disappeared from the presence of Soṇa in Cool Grove and appeared on the Vulture Peak.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.1: After some time, Soṇa exerted a balanced energy, discovered an evenness of the spiritual faculties, and that is where he took up his meditation object.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.2: He then stayed by himself, secluded, heedful, energetic, and diligent. And in this very life, he soon realized with his own insight the supreme goal of the spiritual life for which people from good families rightly go forth from home to homelessness.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.3: He understood that birth had come to an end, that the spiritual life had been lived, that the job had been done, that there was no further state of existence.
pli-tv-kd5:1.18.4: And Venerable Soṇa became one of the perfected ones.
pli-tv-kd5:1.19.2: “Let me declare perfect insight in the presence of the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.19.3: He then went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:1.20.1: “Venerable Sir, a monk who is a perfected one—who has ended the corruptions, lived the spiritual life, done the job, put down the burden, realized the true goal, cut the bond to existence, gained release by right insight—he is committed to six things:
pli-tv-kd5:1.20.2: to renunciation, seclusion, harmlessness, the end of grasping, the end of craving, and non-confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.21.2: ʻNo doubt this venerable is committed to renunciation because of confidence.’ But this is the wrong way to look at it.
pli-tv-kd5:1.21.3: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to renunciation because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.22.2: ʻNo doubt this venerable is committed to seclusion because he desires gain, honor, and fame.’
pli-tv-kd5:1.22.3: But this is the wrong way to look at it.
pli-tv-kd5:1.22.4: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to seclusion because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.23.2: ʻNo doubt this venerable is committed to non-harming because he has fallen back on adhering to conduct and vows as the essence of the spiritual life.’
pli-tv-kd5:1.23.3: But this is the wrong way to look at it.
pli-tv-kd5:1.23.4: The monk who has ended the corruptions, who has lived the spiritual life and done the job, doesn’t see anything to be done in himself or anything to be added to what has already been done. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will. He is committed to harmlessness because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.1: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of sensual desire, because he is without sensual desire.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.2: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of ill will, because he is without ill will.
pli-tv-kd5:1.24.3: He is committed to the end of grasping, to the end of craving, and to non-confusion because of the ending of confusion, because he is without confusion.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.1: Sir, for a monk who is fully freed in this way, even if he sees compelling visual objects, his mind is not overpowered by them.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.2: It remains unaffected, steady, and imperturbable, and he observes its disappearance.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.3: Even if he hears compelling sounds,
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.7: or experiences compelling mental phenomena, his mind is not overpowered by them.
pli-tv-kd5:1.25.8: It remains unaffected, steady, and imperturbable, and he observes its disappearance.
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.1: It’s just like a granite mountain, a single solid mass without cracks. It doesn’t shake or tremble when powerful rainstorms arrive from any direction.
pli-tv-kd5:1.26.5: The mind of the monk who is fully freed in this way is just like that.
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.1: For the one committed to renunciation
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.2: And to seclusion of the mind,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.3: For the one committed to harmlessness
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.4: And to the end of grasping,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.5: For the one committed to the end of craving
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.6: And to non-confusion of the mind,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.7: Having seen the arising of the senses,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.9: For the one who is fully freed,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.10: The monastic with a peaceful mind,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.11: There is nothing more to add
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.12: And nothing that needs to be done.
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.13: Just as a single solid rock,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.15: So too, all visual objects, and sounds,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.17: And mental objects, good and bad,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.18: Cannot move that kind of person.
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.19: Their mind is free and steady,
pli-tv-kd5:1.27.20: And they observe it as it disappears.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.0: The prohibition against sandals with double-layered soles, etc.
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.1: Then the Buddha addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.2: “It’s in this way that someone from a good family declares perfect insight. The matter is spoken of, but the person isn’t mentioned.
pli-tv-kd5:1.28.3: And still some foolish men here seem to declare perfect insight just for fun. Afterward they experience distress because of that.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.1: The Buddha then said to Soṇa,
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.2: “Soṇa, you were brought up in great comfort.
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.3: I allow you to use sandals with single-layered soles.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.4: “When I went forth into homelessness, Sir, I left behind eighty cartloads of gold coins and a group of seven elephants.
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.5: If I were to walk around in sandals with single-layered soles, some people would say, ʻSoṇa left all this behind when he went forth
pli-tv-kd5:1.29.6: and now he’s attached to sandals with single-layered soles.’
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.1: If you allow them to the Sangha of monks, I too will use them.
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.2: If not, I won’t use them either.”
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.3: The Buddha then gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.5: But you should not wear sandals with double-layered soles,
pli-tv-kd5:1.30.8: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.0: The prohibition against what is entirely blue, etc.
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.1: Soon afterwards the monks from the group of six wore entirely blue sandals,
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.9: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.10: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.11: “You should not wear sandals that are entirely blue,
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.12: entirely yellow, entirely red, entirely magenta, entirely black, entirely orange, or entirely beige.
pli-tv-kd5:2.1.13: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.1: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals with blue straps,
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.2: yellow straps, red straps, magenta straps, black straps, orange straps, and beige straps.
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.4: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.6: “You should not wear sandals with blue straps, yellow straps, red straps, magenta straps, black straps, orange straps, or beige straps.
pli-tv-kd5:2.2.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.1: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals containing leather, enclosing the shin and the foot, enclosing the foot, stuffed with cotton, looking like partridge feathers, having strap fasteners made of ram-horn, having strap fasteners made of goat-horn, decorated with scorpion claws, decorated with a peacock’s tail-feather, and decorated in various ways.
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.3: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.5: “You should not wear sandals containing leather,
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.6: enclosing the shin and the foot, enclosing the foot, stuffed with cotton, looking like partridge feathers, having straps fastened with ram-horn, having straps fastened with goat-horn, having straps like scorpion claws, sewn with thread like a peacock’s tail-feather, or decorated in various ways.
pli-tv-kd5:2.3.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.1: At that time the monks from the group of six wore sandals decorated with lion-skin, tiger-skin, leopard-skin, deer-skin, otter-skin, cat-skin, squirrel-skin, and bat-skin.
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.3: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.5: “You should not wear sandals decorated with lion-skin,
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.6: tiger-skin, leopard-skin, deer-skin, otter-skin, cat-skin, squirrel-skin, or bat-skin.
pli-tv-kd5:2.4.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.0: The allowance for second-hand sandals with multi-layered soles
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.1: After robing up one morning, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and entered Rājagaha for almsfood together with an attendant monk.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.2: As he was following behind the Buddha, that monk was limping.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.3: A certain lay follower wearing sandals with multi-layered soles saw the Buddha coming.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.4: He removed his sandals, approached the Buddha, and bowed.
pli-tv-kd5:3.1.5: He then bowed to the attendant monk and asked him,
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.4: “Thanks, but the Buddha has prohibited sandals with multi-layered soles.”
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.5: But the Buddha said, “Please take the sandals.”
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.6: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a Dhamma talk and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.7: “I allow second-hand sandals with multi-layered soles.
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.8: But you should not wear new sandals with multi-layered soles.
pli-tv-kd5:3.2.9: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.0: The prohibition against sandals inside a monastery
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.1: On one occasion the Buddha walked up and down outside without sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.3: The senior monks followed his example,
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.4: but not the monks from the group of six.
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.5: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd5:4.1.6: “How can the monks from the group of six walk up and down with sandals when the Teacher and the senior monks do it without?”
pli-tv-kd5:4.2.1: They told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:4.2.2: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd5:4.2.5: “… How can those foolish men walk up and down with sandals when the Teacher and the senior monks do it without?
pli-tv-kd5:4.2.6: Even the householders who wear white are respectful and deferential toward their teachers for teaching them the profession by which they make a living.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.1: But you who have gone forth on such a well-proclaimed spiritual path will become notorious if you are not respectful and deferential toward your teachers, your preceptors, or those of an equivalent standing.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.2: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.4: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.5: “You should not walk up and down with sandals when your teachers, your preceptors, or those of equivalent standing do it without.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.7: And you should not wear sandals within a monastery.
pli-tv-kd5:4.3.8: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:5.1.1: Soon afterwards a certain monk was afflicted with corns on his feet.
pli-tv-kd5:5.1.2: The monks had to hold him while he urinated and defecated.
pli-tv-kd5:5.1.3: Just then as the Buddha was walking about the dwellings, he saw this. He approached those monks and said to them,
pli-tv-kd5:5.2.2: “He has corns on his feet, Sir.
pli-tv-kd5:5.2.3: That’s why we do this for him.”
pli-tv-kd5:5.2.4: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:5.2.5: “I allow you to wear sandals if your feet are painful or cracked, or you have corns on your feet.”
pli-tv-kd5:6.1.1: The monks used beds and benches with dirty feet.
pli-tv-kd5:6.1.2: Their robes and the furniture became dirty.
pli-tv-kd5:6.1.4: “When you know that you are about to use a bed or bench, I allow you to wear sandals.”
pli-tv-kd5:6.2.1: When monks were going to the observance hall or a meeting in the dark of night, they stepped on stumps and thorns, hurting their feet.
pli-tv-kd5:6.2.3: “I allow you to wear sandals within a monastery, and also to use a torch, a lamp, and a walking stick.”
pli-tv-kd5:6.3.0: The prohibition against wooden shoes, etc.
pli-tv-kd5:6.3.1: At one time the monks from the group of six got up early in the morning, put on wooden shoes, and walked up and down outside. They made a loud clacking noise. And they talked about all sorts of pointless things:
pli-tv-kd5:6.3.2: about kings, gangsters, and officials; about armies, dangers, and battles; about food, drink, clothes, and beds; about garlands and perfumes; about relatives, vehicles, villages, towns, and countries; about women and heroes; gossip; about the departed; about various trivialities; about the world and the sea; about being this or that.
pli-tv-kd5:6.3.3: They stepped on and killed insects, and they roused the monks from the stillness of meditation.
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.1: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.2: “How can the monks from the group of six act like this?”
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.5: They told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.6: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.11: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:6.4.13: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Rājagaha for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Benares.
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.3: he stayed in the deer park at Isipatana.
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.4: When the monks from the group of six knew that
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.5: the Buddha had prohibited wooden shoes,
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.6: they had cuttings made from young palm trees and wore shoes made of palm leaves.
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.9: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
pli-tv-kd5:7.1.11: They are harming life with one sense faculty.”
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.1: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.2: and they told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.3: “Is it true, monks, that the monks from the group of six are acting like this?”
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.7: “… How can those foolish men have cuttings made from young palm trees and wear shoes made of palm leaves,
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.8: when those young palm trees wither as a consequence?
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.10: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.12: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.13: “You should not wear shoes made of palm leaves.
pli-tv-kd5:7.2.14: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.2: the Buddha had prohibited shoes made of palm leaves,
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.3: the monks from the group of six had cuttings made from young bamboo plants and wore shoes made of bamboo leaves.
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.6: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.8: They are harming life with one sense faculty.”
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.9: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.10: and they told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.12: You should not wear shoes made of bamboo leaves.
pli-tv-kd5:7.3.13: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:8.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Benares for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Bhaddiya.
pli-tv-kd5:8.1.3: he stayed in the Jātiyā Grove.
pli-tv-kd5:8.1.4: At that time the monks in Bhaddiya were fond of various kinds of nice shoes. They made shoes of grass, fishtail-palm leaves, and wool, and they had them made. As a consequence, they neglected recitation, questioning, the higher morality, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.1: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.2: “How can the monks in Bhaddiya do this?”
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.3: They told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.4: “Is it true, monks, that the monks in Bhaddiya do this?”
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.8: “… How can those foolish men be fond of various kinds of nice shoes …
pli-tv-kd5:8.2.9: and neglect recitation, questioning, the higher morality, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom?
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.1: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.3: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.4: “You should not wear shoes made of grass, reed, fishtail-palm leaves, or wool; or shoes made with gold, silver, gems, beryl, crystal, bronze, glass, tin, lead, or copper.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.5: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.6: And you should not use shoes for walking.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.7: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.8: I allow three kinds of foot-stands that are fixed in place and immobile:
pli-tv-kd5:8.3.9: foot-stands for defecating, foot-stands for urinating, foot-stands for restroom rinsing.”
pli-tv-kd5:9.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Bhaddiya for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd5:9.1.3: he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-kd5:9.1.4: At this time, when cattle were crossing the Aciravatī river, the monks from the group of six would grab them by the horns, the ears, the neck, and the tail, and they mounted their backs, and motivated by lust, they touched their genitals. They even killed a calf by submerging it.
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.2: “How can the Sakyan ascetics act like this?
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.3: They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.4: The monks heard the complaints of those people
pli-tv-kd5:9.2.5: and they told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.3: the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.4: “You should not grab cattle by the horns, the ears, the neck, or the tail, and you should not mount their backs.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.5: If you do mount their backs, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.6: And you should not touch their genitals motivated by lust.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.7: If you do, you commit a serious offense.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.8: And you should not kill a calf.
pli-tv-kd5:9.3.9: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.1: At that time the monks from the group of six traveled in vehicles, sometimes pulled by women with men inside, at other times pulled by men with women inside.
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.3: “It’s as if they’re at the Ganges festival.”
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.4: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.5: “You should not travel in a vehicle.
pli-tv-kd5:9.4.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.1: Soon afterwards a monk who was traveling through the Kosalan country on his way to visit the Buddha at Sāvatthī became sick.
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.2: He stepped off the path and sat down at the foot of a tree.
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.3: People saw him and said to him,
pli-tv-kd5:10.1.5: “I’m going to Sāvatthī to visit the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.2.4: “Thanks, but the Buddha has prohibited us from traveling in vehicles.” And being afraid of wrongdoing, he did not accept.
pli-tv-kd5:10.2.5: When he arrived at Sāvatthī, he told the monks what had happened,
pli-tv-kd5:10.2.6: who in turn told the Buddha. He said,
pli-tv-kd5:10.2.7: “I allow a vehicle when you’re sick.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.2: “A vehicle pulled by women or by men?”
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.4: “I allow a rickshaw pulled by men.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.5: Soon afterwards a certain monk was even more uncomfortable when jolted around in a vehicle.
pli-tv-kd5:10.3.7: “I allow a palanquin and a litter.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.0: The prohibition against high and luxurious resting places
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.1: At that time the monks from the group of six used high and luxurious resting places, such as:
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.2: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a quilt filled with cotton down, a woolen rug decorated with the images of wild animals, a woolen rug with long fleece on one side, a woolen rug with long fleece on both side, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent rug made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a bed with a canopy, a bed with red cushions at each end.
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.3: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.4: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd5:10.4.5: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:10.5.1: “You should not use high and luxurious resting places, such as:
pli-tv-kd5:10.5.2: a high couch, a luxurious couch, a long-fleeced woolen rug, a multi-colored woolen rug, a white woolen rug, a red woolen rug, a quilt filled with cotton down, a woolen rug decorated with the images of wild animals, a woolen rug with long fleece on one side, a woolen rug with long fleece on both side, a sheet of silk embroidered with gems, a silken sheet, a woolen rug like a dancers’ rug, an elephant-back rug, a horse-back rug, a carriage-seat rug, a rug made of black antelope hide, an excellent sheet made of _kadalī_-deer hide, a bed with a canopy, or a bed with red cushions at each end.
pli-tv-kd5:10.5.3: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.1: Soon afterwards when the monks from the group of six knew that
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.2: the Buddha had prohibited high and luxurious resting places,
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.3: they used luxurious skins: lion skins, tiger skins, and leopard skins.
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.4: They cut them to fit their beds and benches, and used them both there and elsewhere.
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.5: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.6: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.7: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.8: “You should not use luxurious skins: lion skins, tiger skins, or leopard skins.
pli-tv-kd5:10.6.9: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.1: Soon afterwards when the monks from the group of six knew that
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.2: the Buddha had prohibited luxurious skins,
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.4: They cut them to fit their beds and benches, and used them both there and elsewhere.
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.5: At this time a certain bad monk was associating with the family of a bad lay follower.
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.6: One morning that monk robed up, took his bowl and robe, and went to that lay follower’s house, where he sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-kd5:10.7.7: That lay follower approached the monk, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.1: At that time that lay follower had a beautiful young calf with variegated hide, just like a young leopard.
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.2: The bad monk stared at that calf
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.3: and the lay follower asked him why.
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.5: He replied, “I want the skin of that calf.”
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.6: The bad lay follower then slaughtered the calf, skinned it, and gave the skin to the bad monk.
pli-tv-kd5:10.8.7: The monk hid the skin under his upper robe and left.
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.1: The mother-cow, longing for her calf, followed behind him.
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.3: why the cow was following him,
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.4: he replied he did not know.
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.5: But his upper robe was smeared with blood
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.8: When he had told them what had happened,
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.9: they said, “So did you encourage someone to kill?”
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.11: The monks of few desires complained and criticized him,
pli-tv-kd5:10.9.12: “How can a monk encourage someone to kill? Hasn’t the Buddha in many ways criticized killing and praised the abstention from killing?”
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha had the Sangha gathered and questioned that bad monk:
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.2: “Is it true, monk, that you encouraged someone to kill?”
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.4: “Foolish man, how can you encourage someone to kill? Haven’t I in many ways criticized killing and praised the abstention from killing?
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.5: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.6: after rebuking him, the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.8: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.9: And you should not use cattle hide.
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.10: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.11: And you should not use any kind of skin.
pli-tv-kd5:10.10.12: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.0: The allowance regarding the belongings of a householder, etc.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.1: At that time people’s beds and benches were upholstered and covered with skin.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.2: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not sit on them.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.4: “I allow you to sit down on what belongs to a householder, but not to lie down on it.”
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.5: But then the dwellings were held together by straps of leather.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.6: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not sit down.
pli-tv-kd5:11.1.8: “I allow you to sit down against a mere binding made of skin.”
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.1: At that time the monks from the group of six entered the village wearing sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.3: “They are just like householders who indulge in worldly pleasures!”
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.4: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.5: “You should not enter the village wearing sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.6: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.7: Soon afterwards a certain sick monk was not able to enter the village without his sandals.
pli-tv-kd5:12.1.9: “I allow sick monks to enter the village while wearing sandals.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.1: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying in Avantī on Papataka Hill at Kuraraghara.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.2: At that time the lay follower Soṇa Kuṭikaṇṇa was his supporter.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.3: On one occasion Soṇa approached Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.5: “Venerable, the way I understand your teaching, it’s not easy for one who lives at home to lead the spiritual life perfectly complete and pure as a polished conch shell.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.6: I wish to cut off my hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from home into homelessness.
pli-tv-kd5:13.1.7: Please give me the going forth.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.1: “It’s difficult, Soṇa, to live the spiritual life all one’s life, eating one meal a day and sleeping by oneself.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.2: So follow the instruction of the Buddhas while remaining as a householder, and at suitable times you may eat one meal a day, sleep by yourself, and practice celibacy.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.3: As a result, Soṇa’s intention to go forth died down.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.4: A second time Soṇa asked Mahākaccāna for the going forth, but got the same response.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.5: A third time he asked for the going forth
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.11: At that time in the southern region of Avantī, there were few monks.
pli-tv-kd5:13.2.12: Only after three years, with much trouble and difficulty, was Mahākaccāna able to gather a sangha of ten monks from here and there to give the full ordination to Venerable Soṇa.
pli-tv-kd5:13.3.0: The making known of the five favors for Mahākaccāna
pli-tv-kd5:13.3.1: While he was in seclusion after completing the rainy-season residence, Soṇa thought,
pli-tv-kd5:13.3.2: “I’ve heard that the Buddha is like this and like that, but I haven’t seen this for myself. If my preceptor allows me, I shall go and visit the Buddha, the Perfected One, the fully Awakened One.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.3.3: When he had come out from seclusion, Soṇa approached Mahākaccāna, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd5:13.4.6: Please go and visit the Buddha, the perfected and fully awakened one.
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.1: You will see him—pleasing to the eye and inspiring confidence; peaceful in mind and faculties; attained to the supreme subduing and calm; tamed, guarded, and restrained in his sense faculties; a great being.
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.2: Then, Soṇa, in my name, pay respect with your head at the Buddha’s feet and say, ʻ
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.3: Venerable Sir, my preceptor, Venerable Mahākaccāna, pays respect with his head at the Buddha’s feet.’
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.5: ʻIn the southern region of Avantī, Sir, there are few monks. Only after three years, with much trouble and difficulty, was it possible to gather a sangha of ten monks from here and there to give me the full ordination.
pli-tv-kd5:13.5.6: Perhaps the Buddha will allow a smaller group of monks to give the full ordination in Avantī.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.1: In Avantī the ground is dark and hard, made rough by the hooves of cattle.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.2: Perhaps the Buddha will allow sandals with multi-layered soles in Avantī.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.3: In Avantī people value bathing and cleanliness.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.4: Perhaps the Buddha will allow unrestricted bathing in Avantī.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.5: In Avantī sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins are used as rugs,
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.6: just as are _eragu_-grass, chaff-flower grass, _majjāru_-grass, and _jantu_-grass in the central Ganges plain.
pli-tv-kd5:13.6.8: Perhaps the Buddha will allow sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins as rugs in Avantī.
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.1: At present people give robes to monks who are outside the monastic boundary, saying,
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.3: When those monks return to the monastery, they are told,
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.4: “Such-and-such people have given you a robe.” But being afraid of wrongdoing, they don’t accept, thinking,
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.5: “We might commit an offense entailing relinquishment.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.6: Perhaps the Buddha will point out a way to deal with robes.’”
pli-tv-kd5:13.7.8: He got up from his seat, bowed down, and circumambulated Mahākāccāna with his right side toward him. He then put his dwelling in order, took his bowl and robe, and set out for Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.1: When he eventually arrived, he went to the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery, where he approach the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.2: The Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.3: “Ānanda, please prepare a resting place for this newly arrived monk.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.5: “When the Buddha says this, it means he wishes to stay in the same dwelling as Venerable Soṇa.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.8.6: And he prepared a resting place for Soṇa in the Buddha’s dwelling.
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.1: Then, after spending much of the night outside, the Buddha entered the dwelling,
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.3: Rising early in the morning, the Buddha said to Soṇa,
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.5: Saying, “Yes, Sir,” he chanted the entire Chapter of Eights.
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.6: When he was finished, the Buddha said,
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.8: You have learned the Chapter Eights well; you have remembered it well.
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.9: And you have a good voice—it’s clear, articulate, and gets the meaning across.
pli-tv-kd5:13.9.10: How long have you been a monk?”
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.1: “Why did it take you so long to go forth?”
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.2: “I have long seen the danger in worldly pleasures. Still, because household life is crowded and very busy, I was not able to leave.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.3: Seeing the significance of this, the Buddha exclaimed this inspired utterance:
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.4: “Having seen the danger in the world,
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.6: The noble one doesn’t delight in what’s bad;
pli-tv-kd5:13.10.7: In the bad, the pure one doesn’t delight.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.2: “The Buddha approves of me. This is the time to bring up what my preceptor said.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.3: He got up from his seat, put his upper robe over one shoulder, bowed down at the Buddha’s feet, and said,
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.4: “Sir, my preceptor, Venerable Mahākaccāna, pays respect with his head at the Buddha’s feet.” He then repeated everything Mahākaccāna had asked him to say.
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.20: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.21: “In the southern region of Avantī there are few monks.
pli-tv-kd5:13.11.22: In all outlying countries, I allow the full ordination to be given by a group of five, including one expert on the Monastic Law.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.1: In this regard, the following are the outlying countries:
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.2: In the eastern direction there is a town called _Gajaṅgala_, with another town called _Mahāsālā_ on the other side of it. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.3: In the south-eastern direction there is a river called _Sallavatī_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.4: In the southern direction there is a town called _Setakaṇṇika_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.5: In the western direction there is a brahmin village called _Thūṇa_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.12.6: In the northern direction there is a mountain called _Usīraddhaja_. Beyond that are the outlying countries. On the near side are the middle countries.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.1: In Avantī the ground is dark and hard, made rough by the hooves of cattle.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.2: In all outlying countries, I allow sandals with multi-layered soles.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.3: In Avantī people value bathing and cleanliness.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.4: In all outlying countries, I allow unrestricted bathing.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.5: In Avantī sheep-skins, goat-skins, and deer-skins are used as rugs,
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.6: just as are _eragu_-grass, chaff-flower grass, _majjāru_-grass, and _jantu_-grass in the central Ganges plain.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.8: In all outlying countries, I allow rugs of sheep-skin, goat-skin, and deer-skin.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.9: And it may happen that people give robes to monks who are outside the monastic boundary, saying, ʻ
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.10: We give this robe to so-and-so.’
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.11: I allow you to accept it and not start counting the days until you have the robe in your hand.”
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.12: The fifth chapter on skins is finished.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.52: In this chapter there are sixty-three topics.
pli-tv-kd5:13.13.53: The chapter on skins is finished.
